author: By Sarah Gerard
title: Talking to the Dead in the Sunshine State
description: I was searching for facts, for a lost friend, and for what couldn’t be explained.
content: I. THE ROAD TO CASSADAGA
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Marks
title: Ethiopian Workers Are Forced to Return Home, Some With Coronavirus
description: Stigmatized, out of work and facing dangers, migrant laborers are returning by the thousands — and may be fueling a growing outbreak in Ethiopia.
content: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — Unemployed and shunned as possible coronavirus carriers, Ethiopian migrant laborers are returning home by the thousands, placing a huge strain on Ethiopia’s poorly equipped medical system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Puzzlin’
description: Did David Levinson Wilk keep you up with his sparkling grid?
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — David Levinson Wilk has constructed for the Times since 1996, although it’s been a bit since we’ve seen one of his Sundays. He’s been busy: He was a head writer for the recent television iterations of the “$100,000 Pyramid” and “Cash Cab,” and he wrote for “Who Wants to be a Millionaire” for nine years. Those impressive trivia chops come into play today in the fill, and the theme is good wordplay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicola Yoon
title: For Two Teenagers on Election Day, the Political Gets Personal
description: In Brandy Colbert’s “The Voting Booth,” a girl who’s been speaking out since age 7 helps a drummer make his voice heard.
content: I was an adult the first time I volunteered for a presidential campaign. It was in 2008 for Barack Obama. As naïve as it sounds, I felt I was helping America begin to fulfill its promise: to be a place where “all men are created equal.” Fast-forward to today, when America has never seemed farther away from keeping that promise. In a world with so much injustice, how do we maintain hope and a willingness to fight, without burning out, or simply giving in to the easier option of looking the other way?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devi Lockwood
title: How Woody Vines Do the Twist
description: Slowly, scientists are learning how lianas quickly climb.
content: Wood is typically thought of as stiff and rigid, but some wood, in the race upward to access the best sunlight, twists. Lianas, or woody vines, are concentrated in tropical forests; they possess a narrow stem that lets them climb to the top of the canopy, more than 100 feet above the ground, as quickly as possible by twisting their way around tree trunks. Basking in the sun at the top, these vines flower, fruit and lay out new leaves as they photosynthesize.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Magic of Baked Feta
description: Yasmin Fahr’s sheet-pan baked feta, Angela Dimayuga’s black cherry-pistachio salad, and more recipes.
content: The week’s most popular dishes include Yasmin Fahr’s sheet-pan baked feta with broccolini, tomatoes and lemon (above), Angela Dimayuga’s black cherry-pistachio salad with charred scallion vinaigrette and Yewande Komolafe’s spicy cucumbers with yogurt, lemon and herbs. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: U.A.E. Becomes First Arab Nation to Open a Nuclear Power Plant
description: The launch is raising concerns about the growing number of nuclear programs in the volatile Middle East.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The United Arab Emirates became the first Arab country to open a nuclear power plant on Saturday, raising concerns about the long-term consequences of introducing more nuclear programs to the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Robert Gnaizda, Lawyer Who Fought for Social Justice, Dies at 83
description: He challenged redlining banks, employers who discriminated in hiring and, early in his career, Southern counties that thwarted Black voters.
content: Robert Gnaizda, a lawyer whose deft powers of persuasion in defending the civil and economic rights of the poor and minority groups often rendered messy and costly lawsuits against their adversaries a needless last resort, died on July 11 in San Francisco. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Catie Edmondson
title: Alienated by Trump, Suburban Voters Sour on G.O.P. in Battle for the House
description: House Republicans are on the defensive in suburban strongholds as voters reject President Trump’s handling of the coronavirus.
content: BALLWIN, Mo. — For Heather Vaughn, a substitute teacher and graduate student, the decision last month to place the black sign with colorful lettering in her front yard — the one that said, “Black Lives Matter” and “Science is Real” — felt like an act of courage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Iran Says It Detained Leader of California-Based Exile Group
description: The detained man, Jamshid Sharmahd of the Kingdom Assembly of Iran, is accused of planning attacks on Iran, including a 2008 one that killed 14 and injured 200.
content: TEHRAN — Iran on Saturday said it had detained an Iranian-American leader of a little-known, California-based opposition group for allegedly planning a 2008 attack on a mosque that killed 14 people and wounded over 200 others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Víctor Víctor, Known for the Hit ‘Mesita de Noche,’ Dies at 71
description: A singer, songwriter and producer, Mr. Víctor also worked to bring theater, music and dance lessons to underprivileged communities. He died of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Haigney and Peter Arkle
title: The Strange Lives of Objects in the Coronavirus Era
description: The pandemic has inspired a flurry of new and novel items — and given ordinary ones new meanings.
content: Plastic bubbles that hover over restaurant tables. Rods for contactless elevator-button-pushing. Portable seats that attach to lampposts, for shoppers waiting outside crowd-controlled stores. Dresses with skirts that have a six-foot radius. Podlike enclosures to keep gym-goers separate. A plastic sleeve that enables hugging at nursing homes. Masks in every imaginable form.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brianna Holt
title: Yasmin Monet Prince, a New Action Heroine
description: The young British actress stars in “Hanna,” the action drama on Amazon.
content: Name: Yasmin Monet Prince
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: James Silberman, Editor Who Nurtured Literary Careers, Dies at 93
description: At Random House and elsewhere, including his own Summit imprint, he worked with James Baldwin, Marilyn French, Hunter S. Thompson and many others.
content: James Silberman, a revered book editor whose meticulousness, intuition and patience helped propel the publishing careers of a distinguished roster of authors, including James Baldwin, Marilyn French, Hunter S. Thompson and Alvin Toffler, died on July 26 at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Italy Draws a Line Under Genoa Tragedy, Shunting Aside the Benettons
description: The government has leveraged anger over the collapse of Genoa’s Morandi Bridge to take back control of the nation’s highways. But critics say the deal sends a troubling message to investors.
content: ROME — Less than two years after the collapse of the Morandi Bridge in Genoa killed 43 people, Italy will draw a line under the tragedy on Monday when it inaugurates a replacement. But that public celebration has been accompanied by a behind-the-scenes deal that will reshape the running of Italy’s highways as it exacts retribution on the former bridge’s managers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: Lady Red Couture, ‘Mother Hen’ of a Drag Scene, Dies at 43
description: A fixture in Los Angeles clubs who stood 7-foot-2 in heels, she also co-hosted the L.G.B.T.Q. talk show “Hey Qween!”
content: Lady Red Couture, a comedian, singer and talk-show host who called herself “the largest live-singing drag queen in captivity,” and who became a mentor to younger drag performers, died on July 25 in Los Angeles. She was 43.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canada’s Key Role in Creating a Once Awaited Vaccine
description: An American researcher created the polio vaccine, but a Toronto lab and a pioneering female scientist made its mass production possible.
content: Canadians don’t have to go back to 1918 and the start of the Spanish flu pandemic to find an analogy to today. For decades, waves of polio outbreaks gripped the country with fear, death and uncertainty, as recently as the 1950s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Court Frees Michigan Teen Who Was Held for Skipping Online Schoolwork
description: The release came more than a week after a judge ruled that the girl, who violated the terms of her probation by skipping coursework, should remain at the juvenile facility.
content: The Michigan Court of Appeals on Friday freed a 15-year-old suburban Detroit girl whose detention at a juvenile facility drew widespread criticism after a county judge ordered that she be held for failing to complete her online schoolwork.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong and Steve Lohr
title: ByteDance Said to Offer to Sell TikTok’s U.S. Operations
description: The Trump administration has said the video app poses security concerns because of its Chinese ownership.
content: ByteDance, the Chinese internet giant that owns TikTok, has offered to sell all of the popular video app’s American operations as a way to save the business from being banned by the Trump administration, a person with knowledge of the matter said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Schram
title: Edmonton, ‘City of Champions,’ Readies for a Hockey Marathon
description: The N.H.L. chose the small-market, hockey-mad city as one of two “hub cities” — along with Toronto — to host its playoffs.
content: EDMONTON, Alberta — It is said that hockey is the heartbeat of Alberta’s capital city. If that’s so then the 2020 N.H.L. playoffs are like a defibrillator that has shocked the city’s rhythm back to life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: This Sledding Team Trained Hard for Gold in 2010. Some Members Regret It.
description: In skeleton, the headfirst Olympic sledding sport, the opportunity for unlimited training on the track can be a huge advantage. But Canadian Olympians who had such access believe it was bad for their brains.
content: The chance to host the 2010 Winter Games was supposed to be a godsend for Canadian athletes who compete in skeleton, the headfirst sled run down a twisting track.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Seeing America With Megan Rapinoe’ and ‘The Last Narc’
description: The soccer star and activist leads a discussion on HBO, and an Amazon docuseries looks back on the murder of a D.E.A. agent.
content: SEEING AMERICA WITH MEGAN RAPINOE 10 p.m. on HBO. Megan Rapinoe may be one of the biggest stars in sports following the United States women’s national soccer team’s 2019 World Cup victory. But she’s also an outspoken activist for equal pay, racial justice and L.G.B.T.Q. issues. On this special, Rapinoe engages in a discussion with Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, the comedian Hasan Minhaj and the New York Times journalist Nikole Hannah-Jones for a wide-ranging conversation about the upcoming election and societal issues the country is currently facing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Imad Khan
title: Like Old Hollywood Movies, Video Games Get a Polish for New Audiences
description: Game publishers are digging through their vaults to remake or remaster popular titles in a bid to kindle players’ nostalgia.
content: Nostalgia has always been a powerful source of revenue for Hollywood. Turns out, it’s equally lucrative for video games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer
title: Tammy Duckworth Is Nothing and Everything Like Joe Biden
description: Despite their disparate backgrounds, the Illinois Democrat has carved out a public life most evocative of the man she could join on the presidential ticket.
content: Senator Tammy Duckworth, like the man she might serve as vice president, prizes loyalty in her ranks and occasional mischief in her workplace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Federal Agents Don’t Need Army Fatigues
description: If you’re an officer of the law, dress like one. Leave the soldiering to soldiers.
content: Masked men, clad indistinguishably from soldiers, yanking civilians off the street in the dead of night and throwing them into unmarked cars is the modus operandi of totalitarian regimes — or the stuff of dystopian fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon, what should we call an erudite brace of acrostic constructors?
content: ACROSTIC — Today’s passage concerns one of my favorite language categories: collective or group nouns, also known as “terms of venery.” Apparently, many of them were coined centuries ago as hunting terms, and the Latin root ven-, from Venus, applies to the thrill of the chase, be it for love or, well, death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Rich City Tykes Swell Schools in Hamptons and Hudson Valley
description: New York parents of means are seeking less congested classrooms near their second — third? — homes.
content: Carlie Lawrence, 42, a fashion executive and mother of two from Manhattan, was facing the same fear that seemingly every parent of school-age children has these days: what if schools don’t open in the fall?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman, Manny Fernandez and Thomas Fuller
title: After Plummeting, the Virus Soars Back in the Midwest
description: States like Missouri, Illinois and Wisconsin are riding a frustrating seesaw during the pandemic, with new coronavirus cases rising again after apparent progress.
content: CHICAGO — First, the Pacific Northwest and the Northeast were hit hardest as the coronavirus tore through the nation. Then it surged across the South. Now the virus is again picking up dangerous speed in much of the Midwest — and in states from Mississippi to Florida to California that thought they had already seen the worst of it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs
title: Law to Reduce Crack Cocaine Sentences Leaves Some Imprisoned
description: Critics say the First Step Act is being applied too arbitrarily by judges who are taking a hard line when it comes to revisiting nonviolent drug sentences.
content: WASHINGTON — Lazelle Maxwell, 48, is nearly 12 years into a 30-year sentence for a nonviolent crack cocaine charge, a penalty exacerbated by previous run-ins with law enforcement that led to his designation as a career offender.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Connie Culp, First Face Transplant Recipient in U.S., Dies at 57
description: Her near-total face transplant in 2008 was the most complex at the time. She was the fourth patient in the world to undergo such a procedure.
content: Connie Culp, the first patient in the United States to receive a face transplant, died on Wednesday at the Cleveland Clinic, which had performed her procedure in 2008. She was 57.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: ‘Cocktails and Masks Don’t Really Go Together’
description: Young Russians are partying again, seeking a return to normal life and willing to risk a coronavirus surge. “We are people, not robots, and want to have a life,” said a bar patron (and doctor).
content: MOSCOW — When Nest, a cramped Moscow cocktail lounge, reopened for business in late June after more than two months of lockdown, it offered free masks and antiseptic lotion at the entrance to help calm any fears drinkers might have about sitting just inches from each other around tiny round tables.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Glenn Thrush
title: Biden Faces Pressure From Left Over Influence Industry Ties
description: Many of his aides and close allies are veteran Washington hands who have profited from advising big corporations. The Sanders-Warren wing of the party is not happy.
content: WASHINGTON — It was one of the few issues on which President Barack Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. disagreed — how far to go in limiting the influence of lobbyists in government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Marcus
title: The War on Frats
description: Groups of fraternity brothers and sorority sisters are working to kick their organizations off campus.
content: In the past month, hundreds of students have dropped out of their fraternities and sororities at Vanderbilt University. They have gathered, digitally, using group-run Instagram activist pages. They have written searing op-eds condemning their own organizations for the student newspaper, The Vanderbilt Hustler.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: China Wields Its Security Law to Crush Hong Kong Dissent
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 1, 2020.
content: “They are running short of confidence to face the people, to face the people’s choice, to face the people’s demands. It’s fear.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Red Onions Linked to Salmonella Outbreak, Officials Say
description: More than 500 cases and at least 75 hospitalizations have been reported in the United States and Canada, the health authorities said.
content: Red onions grown in California have been traced as the potential source of a salmonella outbreak that has infected more than 500 people in the United States and Canada, health officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Double, Double, Trump’s Toil, Our Trouble
description: Demon sperm meets alien D.N.A., as President Trump teeters.
content: WASHINGTON — Macbeth has his doubts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Adam Goldman
title: Homeland Security Reassigns Official Whose Office Compiled Intelligence on Journalists
description: Brian Murphy’s office compiled reports of protesters and journalists who were covering the Trump administration’s response to unrest in Portland, Ore., last month.
content: WASHINGTON — The head of the Department of Homeland Security’s intelligence branch was removed from his position after his office compiled reports about protesters and journalists covering the Trump administration’s response to unrest in Portland, Ore., last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Mathieu
title: Tank Tops and Short Shorts and Bears, Oh My!
description: In Carrie Firestone’s “Dress Coded,” a middle school’s sexist dress code is more terrifying than the bears wandering through its woods.
content: The Connecticut town where 14-year-old Molly Frost is surviving the end of her eighth-grade year has a bear problem. Bears have taken to wandering into people’s backyards and through the woods near the middle school, forcing the local school board to address the issue and prompting Molly, the main character in Carrie Firestone’s DRESS CODED (Putnam, 320 pp., $17.99; ages 10 and up), to sometimes carry a bear stick for protection.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Infections Swamp the U.S., Which Recorded 42% of All Its Coronavirus Cases in July
description: Thousands in Berlin protest Germany’s coronavirus measures. The virus is picking up speed in the Midwest. A summer camp in Georgia apologizes for hosting a retreat after hundreds who attended were infected.
content: The United States recorded more than 1.9 million new infections in July, nearly 42 percent of the more than 4.5 million cases reported nationwide since the pandemic began and more than double the number documented in any other month, according to data compiled by The New York Times. The previous monthly high came in April, when more than 880,000 new cases were recorded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: Why a Data Breach at a Genealogy Site Has Privacy Experts Worried
description: Nearly two-thirds of GEDmatch’s users opt out of helping law enforcement. For a brief window this month, that didn’t matter.
content: The peculiar matches began early on a Sunday morning. Across the world, genealogists found that they had numerous new relatives on GEDmatch, a website known for its role in helping crack the Golden State Killer case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jodi Levine
title: Turn the News Into a Rose
description: You can make paper flowers as elaborate or a simple as you’d like. A simple bloom is a good place to start.
content: Paper flower-making is a popular craft that can result in blooms as complex and realistic as you want, from dahlias with 100 or more hand-cut, hand-curled crepe petals to coffee filter pom-pom carnations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Mizell
title: W.N.B.A. Rookie Showdown Halted by Ionescu Injury
description: Sabrina Ionescu, who was selected with the top draft pick by the Liberty, sprained her left ankle in a game against the Atlanta Dream.
content: Sabrina Ionescu accidentally stepped on Betnijah Laney’s foot near midcourt, then dropped to the floor after rolling her left ankle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Dr. Eddie Negrón, a Physician Full of Fun, Is Dead at 69
description: Friends remember his jokes and his dancing as well as his medical care. He died of the novel coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 1, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 1, 2020.
content: An article on Page 10 about the Netflix documentary series “Last Chance U” refers imprecisely to coach John Beam. He identifies as multiracial, not white.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: What’s Going On With TikTok? Here’s What We Know
description: President Trump is talking about banning the app. TikTok may also sell its U.S. operations. Let’s sort through it all here.
content: What exactly is going on with TikTok?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adriana Balsamo and Hilary Moss
title: Spend Time with Shakespeare’s Family and Take a Master Class in Ballet
description: As August arrives, you can learn how an author conjured Elizabethan England and engage your children’s five senses in a mystery game.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Protecting the Rights of Those With Disabilities
description: Readers discuss a series of articles about the impact of the Americans With Disabilities Act, passed 30 years ago.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: More Games Postponed With 4 More Coronavirus Cases for Cardinals
description: Three staffers and one player for the St. Louis Cardinals tested positive for the virus, prompting the postponement of a game Saturday and a doubleheader Sunday against the Brewers in Milwaukee.
content: Major League Baseball’s sputtering effort to play in a pandemic took another discouraging turn on Saturday when one St. Louis Cardinals player and three team staffers tested positive for the coronavirus, forcing the postponement of their weekend series in Milwaukee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño and Letícia Casado
title: Under Pressure, Brazil’s Bolsonaro Forced to Fight Deforestation
description: After fending off international criticism on rainforest destruction, President Jair Bolsonaro caved to pressure and took steps to curb deforestation and forest fires.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — A year ago, as fires engulfed the Amazon, President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil reacted to criticism from abroad with indignation: “The Amazon is ours,” he said, arguing that the fate of the rainforest was for his country to decide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Drucker and Robert Gebeloff
title: Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner Report Income of at Least $36 Million in 2019
description: The couple’s investments, mostly in real estate, were worth at least $204 million and as much as $783 million.
content: Three years into their new careers as White House officials, Ivanka Trump, the president’s eldest daughter, and her husband, Jared Kushner, reported income of at least $36 million in 2019, according to financial disclosure reports made public on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, Steve Eder and Michael H. Keller
title: A Better Year for Trump’s Family Business (Last Year, That Is)
description: In 2019, the Trump Organization showed improvement over the previous year. But the company’s minimum reported revenues still fell short of the president’s first year in office, his new financial disclosure shows.
content: Before the coronavirus ripped through the country, upending President Trump’s family business and the broader hospitality industry, the company last year showed modest gains, according to Mr. Trump’s annual financial disclosure report released late Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fahima Haque
title: Celebrating Eid al-Adha Amid a Pandemic
description: With socially distanced gatherings now the norm, we talked to a few people about how they planned to celebrate one of Islam’s holiest days.
content: Most countries observed Eid al-Adha on Friday, and so a belated Eid Mubarak to all who celebrated one of the holiest days in Islam. It is meant to remind Muslims of their faithfulness to Allah and each other, through Zakat, one of the five pillars of the religion that focuses on charity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: In Trumpworld, the Grown-Ups in the Room All Left, and Got Book Deals
description: A large club of Trump administration evictees have turned their bracingly bad experiences into a new genre: political revenge literature.
content: It was the summer of 2016, and the Republican Party was about to nominate Donald J. Trump for president. Until then, many party members had aggressively opposed his candidacy. “I think he’s crazy,” Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, said earlier that year. “I think he’s unfit for office.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: Body Bags and Enemy Lists: How Far-Right Police Officers and Ex-Soldiers Planned for ‘Day X’
description: Germany has woken up to a problem of far-right extremism in its elite special forces. But the threat of neo-Nazi infiltration of state institutions is much broader.
content: GÜSTROW, Germany — The plan sounded frighteningly concrete. The group would round up political enemies and those defending migrants and refugees, put them on trucks and drive them to a secret location.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: SpaceX Crew Dragon Departs, Carrying NASA Astronauts Toward Home
description: Bob Behnken and Doug Hurley are getting ready to splash down after two months in orbit.
content: Two astronauts who took the first commercial trip to orbit have left the International Space Station. They are scheduled to return home on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro, Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio and Shawn Hubler
title: A School Reopens, and the Coronavirus Creeps In
description: As more schools abandon plans for in-person classes, one that opened in Indiana this week had to quarantine students within hours.
content: One of the first school districts in the country to reopen its doors during the coronavirus pandemic did not even make it a day before being forced to grapple with the issue facing every system actively trying to get students into classrooms: What happens when someone comes to school infected?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Isaias Live Updates: Storm Weakens as It Churns Toward Florida After Hitting Bahamas
description: The tropical storm is expected to be upgraded to a hurricane again overnight and may hit Florida’s coast, further testing a state that has been battered by the coronavirus pandemic.
content: After battering the Bahamas and raking parts of Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic with hurricane strength wind and rain, Isaias was downgraded Saturday evening to a tropical storm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How Do I Get My Landlord to Follow Covid-19 Rules?
description: New York issued guidelines for how residential buildings should safely operate — but there no consequences for failing to comply.
content: Q: I live in a Manhattan rental building and staff aren’t wearing masks anymore, much less screening visitors. The building has been lax the whole pandemic, but it’s gotten particularly bad in the last two weeks. I can’t force our neighbors to wear masks, but I am often on the elevator with three or four people, without enough room to safely socially distance. In response to an email, management said, “We can’t enforce anything,” and ignored my second email. I am feeling very unsafe. What can I do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Astead W. Herndon
title: Trump’s Approval Rating, Biden V.P. Search: The Latest in the 2020 Race
description: President Trump’s more sober messaging on the coronavirus crisis didn’t last long. For Joe Biden, the search for a running mate may last a little longer.
content: Welcome to our weekly analysis of the state of the 2020 campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Make Pizza … On Your Grill
description: Bear with us. We know this sounds bonkers, but it really does work.
content: Homemade pizza is great. A 500-degree oven in August is not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Voting by Mail Is Crucial for Democracy
description: Especially amid the pandemic, it’s the surest path to a more inclusive, more accurate and more secure election.
content: For a man who votes by mail himself, Donald Trump is strangely obsessed with the idea that it is the most dangerous method of casting a ballot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu and Eleanor Lutz
title: More Than 1,000 Companies Boycotted Facebook. Did It Work?
description: Major advertisers on Facebook reduced their spending by millions of dollars in July, but not enough to significantly damage the platform’s revenue.
content: The advertiser boycott of Facebook took a toll on the social media giant, but it may have caused more damage to the company’s reputation than to its bottom line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: How to Go to College During a Pandemic
description: Students at Minerva spend four years entirely online. Is this the future of higher education?
content: Hundreds of thousands of undergraduates in America won’t be allowed on their campuses this fall, or the campuses welcoming them will be hollowed-out, locked-down, revelry-leeched shadows of their former selves. What kind of college experience is that?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Trader Joe’s Defends Product Labels Criticized as Racist
description: The company had previously said the names of international-themed products that were intended to promote inclusiveness, such as Trader José and Trader Ming’s, “may now have the opposite effect.”
content: Weeks after admitting that some of its international-themed product labels might have fallen short of an “attempt at inclusiveness,” the grocery store chain Trader Joe’s is rejecting criticism of the labels — some with names like Trader José and Trader Ming’s — as racist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman
title: Indian Billionaires Bet Big on Head Start in Coronavirus Vaccine Race
description: The world’s largest vaccine producer, the Serum Institute, announced a plan to make hundreds of millions of doses of an unproven inoculation. It’s a gamble with a huge upside. And huge risks.
content: PUNE, India — In early May, an extremely well-sealed steel box arrived at the cold room of the Serum Institute of India, the world’s largest vaccine maker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty
title: 12 People in a 3-Bedroom House, Then the Virus Entered the Equation
description: Overcrowding, not density, has defined many coronavirus hot spots. Service workers’ quarters skirting Silicon Valley are no exception.
content: It was not surprising when three-quarters of the house tested positive. There were 12 people in three bedrooms, with a bathroom whose door frequently required a knock and a kitchen where dinnertime shifts extended from 5 p.m. well into the evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iran Will Expand Nuclear Program and Won’t Talk to U.S., Ayatollah Says
description: In a televised speech, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader, said that negotiating with Washington over his country’s nuclear program would only help President Trump get re-elected.
content: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, has said in a televised address that Iran will expand its nuclear program and will not negotiate with the United States, doubling down on his defiance of the Trump administration’s “maximum pressure” policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: Can Humans Give Coronavirus to Bats, and Other Wildlife?
description: Federal agencies suggest caution in U.S. bat research to avoid transmitting the novel coronavirus to wildlife.
content: Many people worry about bats as a source of viruses, including the one that has caused a worldwide pandemic. But another question is surfacing: Could humans pass the novel coronavirus to wildlife, specifically North American bats?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Cusumano
title: How to Stay Safer on Mass Transit
description: Timing your trip strategically, using contactless payments and not eating onboard are some of the things to keep in mind.
content: In cities across the country, ridership on public transportation has dropped precipitously as people have stayed home to help prevent the spread of the coronavirus. But for some, continuing to take mass transit was never optional. Many essential workers who cannot work remotely or don’t drive have continued to ride buses, trains and ferries; they are disproportionately people of color and the earners of lower incomes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Army Officer Who Clashed With Trump Vows to Speak Out on Security Issues
description: Lt. Col. Alexander S. Vindman’s retirement from the Army after more than 21 years of service took effect on Saturday, the same day his sharply critical op-ed of the president was published.
content: An Army officer who was a key witness during the impeachment inquiry into President Trump last year and later retired after what he called a campaign of bullying and intimidation by the president and his allies, sharply criticized the administration on Saturday and said he would use his new civilian status to champion national security issues ahead of the elections in November.
source.name: The New York Times
